content:
XsltSettings Class

In this Article

Specifies the XSLT features to support during execution of the XSLT style sheet.

Syntax

Declaration

public sealed class XsltSettings

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • System.Object
  • XsltSettings

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
,
Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetHashCode()
,
GetType()
,
MemberwiseClone()
,
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
,
ToString()

Remarks

Embedded script blocks and the XSLT document() function are optional features on the XslCompiledTransform class. These features are disabled by default. The XsltSettings class specifies which of these optional features to support. Features are enabled or disabled using the class properties. The XsltSettings object is then passed to the Load method.

Important

XSLT style sheets can include references to other files and embedded script blocks. A malicious user can exploit this by supplying you with data or style sheets that when executed can cause your system to process until the computer runs low on resources. Do not enable scripting or the document() function unless the style sheet comes from a trusted source. If you cannot verify the source of the style sheet, or if the style sheet does not come from a trusted source, use the default XSLT settings.

Constructors summary

XsltSettings()

Initializes a new instance of the XsltSettings class with default settings.
XsltSettings(Boolean,Boolean)

Initializes a new instance of the XsltSettings class with the specified settings.

Properties summary

Default

Gets an XsltSettings object with default settings. Support for the XSLT document() function and embedded script blocks is disabled.
EnableDocumentFunction

Gets or sets a value indicating whether to enable support for the XSLT document() function.
EnableScript

Gets or sets a value indicating whether to enable support for embedded script blocks.
TrustedXslt

Gets an XsltSettings object that enables support for the XSLT document() function and embedded script blocks.

Constructors

  • XsltSettings()

    Initializes a new instance of the XsltSettings class with default settings.

    public XsltSettings ();

    Remarks

    The new XsltSettings object does not support the XSLT document() function or embedded script blocks.

    Important

    XSLT scripting should be enabled only if you require script support and you are working in a fully trusted environment. If you enable the document() function, you can restrict the resources that can be accessed by passing an XmlSecureResolver object to the Transform method.

  • XsltSettings(Boolean,Boolean)

    Initializes a new instance of the XsltSettings class with the specified settings.

    public XsltSettings (bool enableDocumentFunction, bool enableScript);

    Parameters

    • enableDocumentFunction
      Boolean

      true to enable support for the XSLT document() function; otherwise, false.

    • enableScript
      Boolean

      true to enable support for embedded scripts blocks; otherwise, false.

    Remarks

    Important

    XSLT scripting should be enabled only if you require script support and you are working in a fully trusted environment. If you enable the document() function, you can restrict the resources that can be accessed by passing an XmlSecureResolver object to the Transform method.

    Example

    The following example loads a style sheet and enables XSLT script support. 

    ' Create the XsltSettings object with script enabled.
Dim settings As New XsltSettings(False, True)
        
' Create the XslCompiledTransform object and load the style sheet.
Dim xslt As New XslCompiledTransform()
xslt.Load("sort.xsl", settings, New XmlUrlResolver())

    // Create the XsltSettings object with script enabled.
XsltSettings settings = new XsltSettings(false,true);

// Create the XslCompiledTransform object and load the style sheet.
XslCompiledTransform xslt = new XslCompiledTransform();
xslt.Load("sort.xsl", settings, new XmlUrlResolver());

Properties

  • Default

    Gets an XsltSettings object with default settings. Support for the XSLT document() function and embedded script blocks is disabled.

    public static System.Xml.Xsl.XsltSettings Default { get; }

    Property Value

    • XsltSettings

      An XsltSettings object with the stem.Xml.Xsl.XsltSettings.EnableDocumentFunction* and stem.Xml.Xsl.XsltSettings.EnableScript* properties set to false.

    Example

    The following example loads a style sheet with default XSLT settings. 

    ' Create the XslCompiledTransform object and load the style sheet.
Dim xslt As New XslCompiledTransform()
xslt.Load("sort.xsl", XsltSettings.Default, New XmlUrlResolver())

    // Create the XslCompiledTransform object and load the style sheet.
XslCompiledTransform xslt = new XslCompiledTransform();
xslt.Load("sort.xsl", XsltSettings.Default, new XmlUrlResolver());
  • EnableDocumentFunction

    Gets or sets a value indicating whether to enable support for the XSLT document() function.

    public bool EnableDocumentFunction { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Boolean

      true to support the XSLT document() function; otherwise, false. The default is false.

    Remarks

    Important

    If you enable the document() function, you can restrict the resources that can be accessed by passing an XmlSecureResolver object to the Transform method.

  • EnableScript

    Gets or sets a value indicating whether to enable support for embedded script blocks.

    public bool EnableScript { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • Boolean

      true to support script blocks in XSLT style sheets; otherwise, false. The default is false.

    Remarks

    Important

    XSLT scripting should be enabled only if you require script support and you are working in a fully trusted environment.

  • TrustedXslt

    Gets an XsltSettings object that enables support for the XSLT document() function and embedded script blocks.

    public static System.Xml.Xsl.XsltSettings TrustedXslt { get; }

    Property Value

    • XsltSettings

      An XsltSettings object with the stem.Xml.Xsl.XsltSettings.EnableDocumentFunction* and stem.Xml.Xsl.XsltSettings.EnableScript* properties set to true.

    Remarks

    Important

    XSLT scripting should be enabled only if you require script support and you are working in a fully trusted environment. If you enable the document() function, you can restrict the resources that can be accessed by passing an XmlSecureResolver object to the Transform method.

    Example

    The following example loads a style sheet with support for the XSLT document() function and embedded script blocks features enabled. 

    ' Create a resolver and specify the necessary credentials.
Dim resolver As New XmlSecureResolver(New XmlUrlResolver(), "http://serverName/data/")
Dim myCred As System.Net.NetworkCredential
myCred = New System.Net.NetworkCredential(UserName, SecurelyStoredPassword, Domain)
resolver.Credentials = myCred
        
' Create the XslCompiledTransform object and load the style sheet.
Dim xslt As New XslCompiledTransform()
xslt.Load("http://serverName/data/script.xsl", XsltSettings.TrustedXslt, resolver)

    // Create a resolver and specify the necessary credentials.
XmlSecureResolver resolver = new XmlSecureResolver(new XmlUrlResolver(), "http://serverName/data/");
System.Net.NetworkCredential myCred;
myCred  = new System.Net.NetworkCredential(UserName,SecurelyStoredPassword,Domain);  
resolver.Credentials = myCred;

// Create the XslCompiledTransform object and load the style sheet.
XslCompiledTransform xslt = new XslCompiledTransform();
xslt.Load("http://serverName/data/script.xsl", XsltSettings.TrustedXslt, resolver);
